brief_summary.textblock:
A 12-week multicomponent exercise is effective in improving executive function and gait
      performance in dual-task conditions.

clinical_study.brief_title: Exercise Improves Executive Function and Dual-task Decrements

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  age more than 65 years old

          -  ability to walk outdoor independently without assistive devices

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  unstable medical conditions interfering with participation in the study

          -  diagnosis of dementia, psychosis, neurological disease, and depression

          -  unable to receive external information for finishing the neuropsychological tests

facility.name: Department of Physical Therapy and Assistive Technology

clinical_study.official_title: A Multicomponent Exercise Improves Executive Function and Dual-task Decrements in Gait Among Older Adults

primary_outcome.description: velocity (cm/s), stride time (ms), stride length (cm), stride time variability (%) and stride length variability (%) under single- or two dual-task conditions

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: This test consisted of 25-item rating for executive function on tasks. Scores ranged from 0 to 2 for each item, and higher scores indicated worse performance.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Non-Randomized, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Single Blind (Subject), Primary Purpose: Treatment
